header.title: The Greater Key of Solomon, Book Two
header.category: Western Esotericism, Grimoire Magic, Ceremonial Magic

central_thesis: Book Two of The Greater Key of Solomon provides a comprehensive, step-by-step manual for the practical execution of Solomonic magical operations, detailing the stringent requirements for ritual purity, astrological timing, consecration of instruments and spaces, and the authoritative use of Divine Names to successfully evoke and control spirits.

structure_content.chapter_title: PREFATORY NOTE TO BOOK TWO.
structure_content.summary: This note explains that Book Two focuses on how to bring Magical Arts to their proposed end, emphasizing the necessity of understanding the work thoroughly and guarding its secrets from the foolish or ignorant. It warns that success depends on complete mastery of the instructions, even for correcting errors.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter I. AT WHAT HOUR AFTER THE PREPARATION OF ALL THINGS NECESSARY, WE SHOULD BRING THE EXERCISE OF THE ART TO PERFECTION
structure_content.summary: This chapter details specific astrological timings for various operations: Mercury's hours (16th, 23rd, or 8th night) for spirit communication; Moon's days/hours (during increase, 1st-8th day hour, or 3rd/5th night hour) for stolen items; Mars's hours (1st-3rd day/night) for invisibility; Sun's/Venus's hours (1st-8th day) for love/favor; Saturn's hours (1st, 8th, or 15th day, or 1st-8th night) for destruction/desolation; and Venus's hours (1st, 8th day, 3rd, 7th night) for games/illusions. All operations generally require an increasing Moon and specific Zodiac signs. It stresses conducting experiments in clear, calm weather and in secret, uninhabited places, and that interrupted operations should be recommenced without new preparations, as their virtue derives from the initial timing.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter II. IN WHAT MANNER THE MASTER OF THE ART SHOULD KEEP, RULE, AND GOVERN HIMSELF.
structure_content.summary: The Master must maintain mental freedom from distractions, thoroughly understand the operation, and meticulously prepare materials. A secret, private location is essential. Before operations, the Master must strip naked, bathe in exorcised water while reciting a purification prayer, and then dress in pure white linen. A three-day period of abstinence from 'idle, vain, and impure reasonings', impurity, and sin is required, accompanied by specific daily prayers and a full fast on the final day.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter III. HOW THE COMPANIONS OR DISCIPLES OF THE MASTER OF THE ART OUGHT TO REGULATE AND GOVERN THEMSELVES.
structure_content.summary: Companions (three, five, seven, or nine in number, or a faithful dog or child) are required and must be bound by oath to implicitly obey the Master, lest they face spiritual dangers. They undergo a purification ritual similar to the Master's: bathing in exorcised water with a regeneration prayer, donning white robes, and fasting. Dog or child companions receive a special conjuration for fidelity and assistance. All participants must wear consecrated Pentacles for protection.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter IV. CONCERNING THE FASTING, CARE, AND THINGS TO BE OBSERVED.
structure_content.summary: This chapter elaborates on the nine-day preparatory period for both Master and Disciples, emphasizing strict moral and physical purity: abstinence from unlawful acts, impiety, impurity, gluttony, and vain discourse. Instead, good deeds and modesty are required. A specific conjuration is recited daily. The last three days involve a minimal 'fasting diet' (preferably bread and water), with a complete fast on the final day. Confession and a final purification with hyssop and exorcised water precede the operation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter V. CONCERNING THE BATHS, AND HOW THEY ARE TO BE ARRANGED.
structure_content.summary: Details the ritual bath process: disrobing while reciting Psalms, exorcising the water to reveal deceits and cleanse impurities, washing while invoking Divine Names (MERTALIA, MUSALIA, ADONAI, TETRAGRAMMATON), sprinkling with exorcised water, and redressing while reciting more Psalms and a concluding prayer. Salt is blessed and added to the bath, followed by a second immersion and further recitations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter VI. OF THE GARMENTS AND SHOES OF THE ART.
structure_content.summary: The Master's ritual garments are specified as white linen or silk, spun by a young maiden, with characters (Figure 55) embroidered in red silk on the breast. White leather shoes with inscribed characters (Figure 56) are made during the fasting period. The Master's crown is virgin parchment, inscribed with Divine Names (YOD HE VAU HE, ADONAI, EL, ELOHIM) in the ink of Art (Figure 57); Disciples' crowns have scarlet symbols (Figure 58). Robing is accompanied by Psalms and an invocation (AMOR, AMATOR, AMIDES...), followed by perfuming. Priestly vestments are preferred if available.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter VII. OF PLACES WHEREIN WE MAY CONVENIENTLY EXECUTE THE EXPERIMENTS AND OPERATIONS OF THE ART
structure_content.summary: Ideal locations are remote, uninhabited places like forests, caves, or crossroads at night, or a purified room within the practitioner's home. The chosen area must be thoroughly cleansed while reciting Psalms, then perfumed and sprinkled with exorcised water. Before entering the operational space, a specific prayer (ZAZAII, ZAMAII, PUIDAMON...) is recited, and the path is sprinkled. Disciples are assigned to carry specific consecrated instruments for the ritual.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter VIII. OF THE KNIFE, SWORD, SICKLE, PONIARD, DAGGER, LANCE, WAND, STAFF, AND OTHER INSTRUMENTS OF MAGICAL ART.
structure_content.summary: Provides detailed instructions for creating and consecrating various steel instruments (knives, scimitar, sickle, dagger, poniard, lance, sword), a staff, and a wand. Each instrument has specific material requirements, astrological timings for creation, methods of dipping in animal blood/herb juice, engraved characters (Figures 61-70, 71-79), hilt inscriptions, and consecratory prayers/perfumes. For instance, the white-hilted knife is for general operations, while the black-hilted knife is specifically for drawing the Circle and compelling spirits. The staff and wand are made from virgin wood.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter IX. OF THE FORMATION OF THE CIRCLE.
structure_content.summary: This chapter outlines the precise construction of the magical Circle. A nine-foot radius is traced using a sickle/scimitar and cord. Multiple concentric circles are drawn (Figure 81), with an entry/exit point to the North. Pentagrams with Divine Symbols and Names surround the outer circles. A square encompasses these, aligned with cardinal directions, with lesser circles at the corners for censers. The Magus leads Disciples into the Circle, exhorts them, kindles incense, re-enters, closes the entrance, and sounds a consecrated trumpet (inscribed with ELOHIM GIBOR, ELOHIM TZABAOTH, Figures 59-60) towards the four quarters before commencing invocations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter X. CONCERNING INCENSE, SUFFUMIGATIONS, PERFUMES, ODOURS, AND SIMILAR THINGS WHICH ARE USED IN MAGICAL ARTS.
structure_content.summary: Incense and perfumes are categorized by their intended use: sweet odours (aloes, nutmeg, gum benjamin, musk) for good spirits, and 'evil odours' for adverse entities. Specific exorcisms are provided for incense (to attract good spirits and banish phantoms), the fire used to burn it, and fumigations of evil odour. All spices are sprinkled with Water of Art and stored appropriately.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XI. OF THE WATER, AND OF THE HYSSOP.
structure_content.summary: Instructions for preparing exorcised water and a sprinkler. Clear spring water is placed in a non-iron vessel, and blessed salt (TZABAOTH, MESSIACH, EMANUEL, ELOHIM GIBOR, YOD HE VAU HE) is added, with Psalms recited. A sprinkler is fashioned from specific herbs (vervain, fennel, lavender, sage, valerian, mint, garden-basil, rosemary, hyssop), bound with maiden-spun thread, and inscribed with characters (Figures 82-83). This exorcised water, used with the sprinkler, is said to banish phantoms and is used for all ritual preparations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XII. OF THE LIGHT, AND OF THE FIRE.
structure_content.summary: Emphasizes the ritual importance of light. Candles of virgin wax, weighing half a pound each, are made with maiden-spun wicks during Mercury's day/hour (Moon increasing) and engraved with characters (Figure 84) using the Dagger or Burin. They are then consecrated with Psalms and prayers to grant understanding, banish phantasms, and invoke divine grace. A separate exorcism is given for the fire when kindling the candles, invoking YOD, HE, VAU, HE, IAH, and EL to ensure spirits appear without deceit. A square lantern with crystal panes holds the lighted candle.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XIII. CONCERNING THE PRECEPTS OF THE ART.
structure_content.summary: This chapter reiterates the Magus's and Disciples' nine-day preparatory period of purity and consecration. Upon entering the Circle, the Master exhorts Disciples to fear nothing, then uncovers and shows the Holy Pentacles to the four quarters, which causes spiritual commotions. The 'Emperor of Spirits' then speaks, acknowledging the power of the Solomonic rites. Petitions written on virgin parchment are presented to the spirits, who counsel and fulfill the requests.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XIV. OF THE PEN, INK, AND COLOURS.
structure_content.summary: Instructions for preparing writing tools: a pen from a male gosling's third right wing feather, conjured (ADRAI, HAHLII, TAMAII...) for efficacy, sharpened, perfumed, and wrapped in silk. An inkstand is made on Mercury's day/hour, inscribed with Divine Names (YOD, HE, VAU, HE, Metatron, Iah Iah Iah, Qadosch, Elohim Tzabaoth, Figure 85). Ink is exorcised (ANAIRETON, SIMULATOR, ADONAI) to imbue it with aid. Various noble colors are also prepared and consecrated similarly.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XV. OF THE PEN OF THE SWALLOW AND OF THE CROW.
structure_content.summary: An alternative pen made from a swallow or crow feather. Before plucking, Archangel MICHAEL and MIDAEL/MIRAEL are invoked for aid in writing. The pen is shaped with the Knife of Art, inscribed with ANAIRETON (Figure 86), and consecrated with Psalms cxxxiii and cxvii.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XVI. OF THE BLOOD OF THE BAT, PIGEON, AND OTHER ANIMALS.
structure_content.summary: Describes how to obtain and consecrate animal blood for operations. A living bat (or other virgin winged animal) is exorcised (CAMIACH, EMOIAHE, EMIAL...) to assist. Its blood is then drawn from the right wing vein with the Needle of Art, collected, and invoked over (ADONAI, ARATHRON, ASHAI...) to imbue it with power. The blood is then perfumed and stored.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XVII. OF VIRGIN PARCHMENT, OR VIRGIN PAPER, AND HOW IT SHOULD BE PREPARED.
structure_content.summary: This chapter details two types of parchment: 'Virgin' (from ungenerated lambs) and 'Unborn' (from an animal taken from its mother's uterus), preferably male, prepared on Mercury's day/hour. A marsh-reed is fashioned into a knife, inscribed with AGLA, ADONAI, ELOHI (Figure 87), and used to flay the animal after reciting Psalm lxxii and a conjuration to EL SHADDAI. The flayed skin is rubbed with exorcised salt, dried in the sun, then immersed for three days in lime and exorcised water (in a vessel inscribed with Figure 88 characters). After scraping, it is stretched within a circle using a hazel wand, maiden-spun cord, and blessed pebbles, then consecrated with Divine Names, dried, and stored. A quicker but less potent method is also described, as well as substitutes like child's cauls or silk/paper.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XVIII. OF WAX AND VIRGIN EARTH.
structure_content.summary: Instructions for preparing virgin wax (from bees' first-time comb) and virgin earth (dug by hand without instruments). Both must be unused and are consecrated with a conjuration (EXTABOR, HETABOR, SITTACIBOR...), Psalms, and an exorcism (through ADONAI) to imbue them with virtue. They are then sprinkled and stored for use in images, candles, or other items.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XIX. CONCERNING THE NEEDLE AND OTHER IRON INSTRUMENTS.
structure_content.summary: Details the consecration of steel instruments like needles and burins. Made on Jupiter's day/hour, they are conjured ('O Instrument of Steel...') by God the Father Almighty and the virtues of celestial bodies and elements to achieve desired ends without deceit. Psalms are recited, and the instruments are perfumed, sprinkled with exorcised water, wrapped in silk, and dedicated with an invocation to Angels (DANI, ZUMECH, AGALMATUROD...).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XX. CONCERNING THE SILKEN CLOTH.
structure_content.summary: Describes the silken cloth used to wrap consecrated instruments. It must be any color except black or grey, inscribed with words and characters (Figure 90), perfumed, sprinkled with water, and consecrated by reciting Psalms. It is then stored for seven days with sweet spices before use.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXI. CONCERNING CHARACTERS, AND THE CONSECRATION OF THE MAGICAL BOOK.
structure_content.summary: Instructions for writing magical characters, placing EHIEH ASHER EHIEH (Figure 91) at the start and AIN SOPH (Figure 92) at the end, and praying for divine virtue. For the 'Magical Book' (16 virgin parchment pages with prayers, Angelic names, seals, and characters), red ink is used. It's consecrated over seven days (beginning Saturday) on a white-cloth-covered table under a suspended lamp, within white curtains. The Magus, in vestments, kneels and recites the 'Adonai Elohim' prayer, incensing the book with planetary incense. The book is then stored. It emphasizes summoning Angels via Litanies and perseverance, warning against impure intentions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXII. CONCERNING SACRIFICES TO THE SPIRITS, AND HOW THEY SHOULD BE MADE.
structure_content.summary: This chapter outlines the offering of sacrifices to spirits: white animals for good spirits, black for evil, often involving blood or flesh from virgin creatures. Before offering, a prayer is recited, and the offering is perfumed and sprinkled. Fire sacrifices use specific woods corresponding to planetary influences. Food and drink offerings (bread, wine, water) are prepared outside the Circle, covered, consecrated, and presented after summoning spirits by their proper names. The room is first perfumed and viands sprinkled.

structure_content.chapter_title: Conclusion
structure_content.summary: The conclusion asserts that complete understanding and strict adherence to the 'Key' are essential for success in all magical operations. It states that the book contains 'all science of Magical Art' and must be diligently preserved, attributing ultimate authority to God.

structure_content.chapter_title: ANCIENT FRAGMENT OF THE KEY OF SOLOMON
structure_content.summary: This fragment, attributed to Eliphaz Levi, presents a Qabalistic framework for understanding spirit hierarchies. Spirits are defined as dignities or degrees on the 'Sacred Ladder', not persons. It maps the ten Sephiroth (Kether, Chokmah, Binah, Gedulah/Chesed, Geburah/Justice, Tiphereth, Netzach, Hod, Yesod, Malkuth) to specific angelic orders (e.g., Chaioth Ha-Qadesh, Auphanim, Aralim) and their corresponding adversarial demonic counterparts (e.g., Thamiel, Chaigidel, Satariel), with their respective chiefs. It links the Divine Tetragram with the Pentagram, symbolizing the vanquishing of 'accursed nations'. It philosophically distinguishes between Heaven (Supreme Reason) and Hell (Folly) for the wise, and dismisses hallucination methods as crimes against nature. The fragment concludes with King Solomon's insights on the Schema Hamphorasch, the Thirty-two Paths of Yetzirah, and the creation of thirty-six Talismans inscribed with Divine Names to control spirits.

structure_content.chapter_title: THE QABALISTICAL INVOCATION OF SOLOMON
structure_content.summary: Presented by Eliphaz Levi, this is a potent Qabalistic invocation designed to connect the practitioner with the powers of the Sephiroth and their associated angelic hosts. It calls upon various Divine Names and angelic orders (e.g., GEDULAHEL, GEBURAHEL, BINAHEL, RUACH CHOKMAHEL, KETHERIEL, Ishim, Cherubim, Beni Elohim, Elohim, Malachim, Seraphim, Chaschmalim, Aralim, Auphanim, Chaioth Ha-Qadosch) to align the practitioner with divine authority, receive guidance, protection, and strength, culminating in expressions of praise ('Halelu-Yah').

key_concepts.definition: A fundamental prerequisite for the Master and Disciples, encompassing physical cleanliness (ritual baths), mental discipline (abstinence from 'idle, vain, and impure reasonings'), and moral rectitude (abstinence from sin, impurity, gluttony), enforced through specific prayers and fasting periods.

The process of ritually purifying, blessing, and empowering all instruments, materials (e.g., water, salt, wax, parchment, ink), garments, and spaces used in magical operations. This is achieved through specific prayers, exorcisms, recitation of Psalms, and anointing with perfumed substances or water, imbuing them with magical efficacy and divine sanction.

A meticulously constructed, multi-layered ritual boundary, typically nine feet in radius, inscribed with Divine Names, symbols, and pentagrams. It serves as a protective sanctuary for the practitioner during evocations and as a focal point to contain and control summoned spirits. Precise measurements and cardinal orientations are critical.

The precise selection of specific days, hours (planetary hours), lunar phases (e.g., increasing moon), and zodiacal signs that correspond sympathetically to the nature of the desired magical operation. This alignment is deemed essential to harmonize the ritual with cosmic energies and maximize its success.

Sacred Hebrew names of God (e.g., YOD HE VAU HE, ADONAI, ELOHIM, SHADDAI, AGLA, TETRAGRAMMATON) and angelic titles invoked throughout the rituals. These names carry inherent power and authority, used in conjurations, exorcisms, and consecrations to command spirits and imbue objects with virtue.

A detailed classification of spiritual entities, derived from Qabalistic principles, associating specific angelic orders (e.g., Chaioth Ha-Qadesh, Auphanim) with the ten Sephiroth of the Tree of Life, and their adversarial demonic counterparts (e.g., Thamiel, Chaigidel) with associated chiefs. This framework provides a systematic understanding of the unseen forces engaged in evocation.

Consecrated talismans, often inscribed with divine names and symbols, worn by the Master and Disciples over their breasts. They serve as powerful protective devices and sources of assurance against malevolent spiritual influences during operations.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in Book Two is a highly structured, hierarchical, and performative ceremonial magic tradition focused on the evocation of spirits for various purposes. It mandates extensive purification rites for the Master and Disciples, precise astrological timing, and the meticulous consecration of all magical tools, garments, and ritual spaces. Success is contingent upon absolute adherence to every detail and the authoritative invocation of Divine Names to compel spirits to appear and obey. The system aims to grant the practitioner control over spiritual entities to achieve specific mundane or spiritual objectives, emphasizing protection through the consecrated Circle and Pentacles.
tools: Ritual garments (white linen or silk), shoes, and crowns (virgin parchment for Master, scarlet symbols for Disciples).
Consecrated Pentacles for protection, worn over the breast.
Specialized knives (white-hilted for general use, black-hilted for the Circle/compelling spirits), Scimitar, Sickle, Dagger, Poniard, Short Lance, and Magical Sword (all consecrated steel).
Wand (hazel or nut tree) and Staff (elderwood, cane, or rosewood), made from virgin wood.
Censer and various incenses (sweet for good spirits, 'evil' for adverse entities).
Exorcised water and a consecrated hyssop sprinkler (made from specific herbs).
Consecrated candles (virgin wax) and a square lantern with crystal panes.
Consecrated Trumpet, inscribed with Divine Names.
Virgin Parchment or Unborn Parchment (alternatives: child's cauls, paper, silk).
Exorcised ink and pens (gosling, swallow, or crow feathers).
Specific noble colors for inscriptions (yellow/gold, red, celestial blue, green, brown).
Blood of virgin animals (bat, pigeon, etc.).
Magical Book (16 virgin parchment pages, consecrated, containing prayers, names, seals, and characters).
rituals: Ritual Baths and Purifications for Master, Disciples, and animal companions.
Nine-day period of fasting and moral abstinence.
Recitation of specific Psalms and prayers for consecration, protection, and divine aid.
Exorcisms for all ritual materials: water, fire, incense, salt, ink, parchment, and instruments.
Construction and consecration of the Magical Circle with precise measurements, inscriptions, and alignment.
Evocation of spirits using specific conjurations and the sounding of a consecrated trumpet towards cardinal points.
Presentation of written petitions to the evoked spirits and receiving their counsel/fulfillment.
Offering of sacrifices (blood, fire, food, drink) appropriate to the nature of the invoked spirits.
Qabalistic invocations for spiritual alignment and empowerment.

relevant_quotes.text: THIS work of SOLOMON is divided into Two Books. In the first thou mayest see and know how to avoid errors in Experiments, Operations, and in the Spirits theirselves. In the second thou art taught in what manner Magical Arts may be reduced to the proposed object and end.

Any Art or Operation of this kind will not be able to attain its end, unless the Master of the Art, or Exorcist, shall have this work completely in his power, that is to say, unless he thoroughly understand it, for without this he will never attain the effect of any operation.

For this reason I earnestly pray and conjure the person into whose hands this Key of Secrets may fall, neither to communicate it, nor to make any one a partaker in this knowledge, if he be not faithful, nor capable of keeping a secret, nor expert in the Arts.
If then thou shouldst operate touching anything which hath been stolen... it is necessary to practice it on the days and hours of the Moon, being if possible in her increase...

Be ye regenerate, cleansed, and purified, in the Name of the Ineffable, Great, and Eternal God, from all your iniquities, and may the virtue of the Most High descend upon you and abide with you always, so that ye may have the power and strength to accomplish the desires of your heart. Amen.

I conjure thee, O Creature, being a Dog, by Him Who hath created thee, I bathe and I perfume thee in the Name of the Most High, Most Powerful, and Eternal God, so that thou mayest be my true Companion in this operation, and that thou mayest he also my faithful friend in whatsoever Operation I may hereafter perform.
The Spirits are governed by the natural and universal Hierarchy of things. Thrice command Three through the medium of Three.

The Spirits of Gedulah are the Chaschmalim, or the Lucid Ones. Their empire is that of beneficence; they correspond to the imagination. They have for adversaries the Gamchicoth or the Disturbers of Souls. The Chief or Guide of these Demons is Ashtaroth or Astarte...

critical_analysis.relevance: The Greater Key of Solomon, Book Two, is a pivotal text in Western Esotericism, forming the bedrock of many ceremonial magic traditions. Its exhaustive detailing of ritual preparations, purity requirements, astrological timing, and instrument consecration has profoundly influenced subsequent grimoires and modern occult systems (e.g., Golden Dawn, Thelema). The emphasis on divine authority and precise execution reflects a classical Hermetic-Qabalistic paradigm, where sympathetic correspondences and hierarchical control are central. Eliphaz Levi's appended fragment further integrates the practical grimoire operations into a sophisticated Qabalistic cosmology, demonstrating an ongoing effort to intellectualize and systematize Solomonic magic within a broader philosophical framework, thus making it highly relevant for understanding the evolution of magical theory and practice.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This text is intended for dedicated initiates and experienced practitioners of ceremonial magic, particularly those within the Solomonic tradition or related Hermetic and Qabalistic systems. It is not suitable for casual readers or beginners due to its demanding requirements for ritual purity, exact astrological calculations, meticulous instrument preparation, and the authoritative, often dangerous, nature of spirit evocation. The text assumes a pre-existing commitment to rigorous discipline and a willingness to invest significant time and resources into preparatory rites.
